awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Marissa Loving is "The Mapping Class Group and Geometric Structures on Surfaces". The host institution for the fellowship is Georgia Institute of Technology and the sponsoring scientist is Dan Margalit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the duration of the fellowship, the PI focused on the study of 2 and 3-dimensional shapes called manifolds which have simple local structure, but more interesting global properties. For example, if you stand in the middle of the road the ground around you just looks like a flat little disk, but if you zoom out far enough you can see that the earth is in fact a sphere not a plane. The PIs research relates the symmetries of 2-manifolds, called surfaces, to the geometry of associated 3-manifolds. The PI also studies the way that lengths of curves on a surface can determine the geometric structure on that surface. Thus, most of the PIs work involves the interplay between geometry, topology, and dynamics in dimensions 1, 2, and 3.

The PI published several papers and preprints on these topics throughout the fellowship period which have since appeared in journals such as the Journal of Topology and the Michigan Mathematical Journal.

Along with this research progress, the PI was active in work intended to broaden pathways for participation in mathematics. The PI was one of the organizers of the Topology Student Workshop in summer 2020, a co-founder and organizer of the SUBgroups program, which provides peer mentoring and support to incoming math graduate students, and a co-founder and organizer of the paraDIGMS (Diversity in Graduate Mathematical Sciences) program. The PI also ran an REU in summer 2021 with a group of four undergraduate math majors all of whom were from groups historically excluded from academic mathematics. That REU resulted in a paper which has recently been accepted for publication in the Journal of Knot Theory and its Ramifications.
